From: Tim Magnussen <tmagnussen@...>

tim@wolf:~$ java -version
java version "1.3.0"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition
(build Blackdown-1.3.0-FCS)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build Blackdown-1.3.0-FCS,
mixed mode)

Oops - you are absolutely right in the sense that I'm
not running the java version I had thought. Turns out
that another javac and java had precedence in the path
(from my Debian installation).

Thans for your help!

--- Scott Stirling <sstirling@...> wrote:
> You sure you're using the JDK 1.3.1 and not kaffe by
> accident?  What do you
> get when you do "java -version"?
> 
> I am using JUnit 3.7 on RedHat Linux 7.1 with Sun's
> 1.3.1 JDK and IBM's
> 1.3.0 JDK.
> 
> JDK 1.3.1 is not indifferent to CLASSPATH (which is
> another thing that makes
> me wonder if you're using kaffe).  Even so, you can
> use -cp instead of
> -classpath or the CLASSPATH environment variable if
> you prefer.
> 
> Scott
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Tim Magnussen
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: 7/17/01 3:50 PM
> Subject: [junit] .jar file for JDK 1.3.1
> 
> Hi there. I'm quite new to JUnit and Java but have
> used the C++
> equivalent for some time.
> I'm using JDK 1.3.1 for Linux.
> The junit package is downloaded and installed it on
> my local filesystem.
> Two things:
> 1) The junit documentation tells you to include
> junit.jar in
> CLASSPATH, but apparently javac for 1.3.1 is
> indifferent to CLASSPATH
> and I could only make it work by specifying "javac
> -classpath
> ~/blabla/junit.jar".
> 2)The junit.jar file is apparently compiled
> especially for JDK 1.2.2 -
> alas I could not compile with javac. I found out
> that "oldjavac" and
> "oldjava" did work and so I'm using them instead but
> this seems like a
> wrong way to solve things.
> 
> I think all these problems could be solved with a
> junit.jar that is
> compiled for 1.3.1 but haven't been able to find
> one. Is anyone aware
> of a place where one can download this?
> 
> Thanks
> /Tim
